awd_titl_txt: MRI:  Acquisition of Leica STED Super-resolution and FALCON Microscope System for the Clemson Light Imaging Facility
awd_abstract_narration:
An award is made to Clemson University to acquire super-resolution fluorescence lifetime imaging system upgrades to an existing multiphoton/spectral confocal imaging system. These added capabilities will significantly enhance the research objectives of more than 30 principle investigators at Clemson University. As this equipment will be placed in Clemson Light Imaging Facility, a core research facility, it will be accessible by the entire Clemson research community and to the extended Clemson research family, including nearby universities and businesses, through collaborative partnerships and outreach programs. From nanoparticles to cellular exosomes and organelles, there is a great need for increased resolution in fluorescence-based imaging studies, which the super-resolution capacity will provide. The fluorescence lifetime imaging system generates images based upon the decay of a fluorophore's fluorescence. This "lifetime" provides information about the fluorophore's direct environment, producing an image that contains not only structural information, but information about pH, ion concentrations, reduced oxygen species, and molecular binding as well. These systems will serve as avenues of training in advanced imaging techniques for the next generation of great researchers and inventors. At Clemson University, this current cohort of scientists is made of undergraduates, graduate students and postdocs/technicians.

With the increased resolution afforded by super-resolution, researchers can visualize extremely small structures such as cellular exosomes, which play a role in cell-cell communication. Studies of actin filament formation dynamics in ciliated organisms can lead to new insights in cell motility, and in neuronal dendrites, where actin controls the size and shape of synaptic connections, scientists can begin to unravel the mysteries of learning and memory in the brain. The addition of the fluorescence lifetime imaging system will provide unprecedented imaging capabilities for tracking changes in cellular structure and metabolism within microenvironments from biofilms to tissues. The additional environmental data generated through fluorescence lifetime imaging will enable greater coupling of molecular modeling and experimental efforts, enabling the development of more robust simulations that can aide biologists and even engineers. Images and data generated through the use of these systems will be publicly disseminated through a variety of peer-reviewed journals and publications as well as at scientific meetings.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This project provided funds for the acquisition of three-color stimulated emission depletion (STED) super-resolution microscopy (SRM) and fast lifetime contrast (FALCON) fluorescence lifetime imaging (FLIM) system upgrades to an existing Leica SP8 multiphoton/spectral confocal imaging system. These added capabilities have significantly enhanced the research objectives of multiple principle investigators at Clemson University. The system is housed in the Clemson Light Imaging Facility (CLIF), which is the only dedicated light microscopy imaging facility at Clemson University. The CLIF user base currently includes over 200 researchers and graduate students from more than 100 research groups and businesses. The Clemson University researchers represent the following departments: Biological Sciences, Genetics & Biochemistry, Bioengineering, Chemical and Biomolecular Engineering, Materials Science and Engineering, Mechanical Engineering, Chemistry, Physics & Astronomy, and Plant & Environmental Science.

Intellectual Merit  Light microscopy has long been a necessary tool for biological research. The power of live-cell imaging has allowed us to literally ?see? dynamic cellular events as they occur, and we can now visualize these events at resolutions (~20 nm) previously thought impossible with light! The addition of the STED SRM to the CLIF allows Clemson researchers to image specimens at much higher resolution than attainable with traditional fluorescence-based imaging methods, such as confocal laser scanning microscopy. SRM provides remarkable image data enrichment from which researchers can extract information previously unavailable to them. The FALCON FLIM system generates images based upon the exponential decay of a fluorophore?s fluorescence. This ?lifetime? provides information about the fluorophore?s direct environment, producing an image that contains not only structural information, but information about pH, ion concentrations, reduced oxygen species, and molecular binding. This system upgrade is providing unprecedented imaging capabilities for tracking changes in cellular structure and metabolism within microenvironments from biofilms to tissues.

 

Broader Impacts   As this equipment was placed in CLIF, it is accessible by the entire Clemson research community and to the extended Clemson research family, including the Prisma Hospital System and other nearby universities and businesses, through collaborative partnerships and outreach programs. A number of Clemson researchers are now employing SRM and FLIM in their research. From nanoparticles to cellular exosomes and organelles, the new system provides increased resolution in fluorescence-based imaging studies. With the increased resolution afforded by the STED SRM, we can visualize cellular exosomes, which play a role in cell-cell communication, and functionalized nanoparticles that may one day lead to the development of new genetic therapy methods and cancer treatments. Studies of actin filament formation dynamics in ciliated organisms can lead to new drug treatments for ciliopathies, and in neuronal dendrites, where actin controls the size and shape of synaptic connections, we can begin to unravel the mysteries of learning and memory in the brain. The additional environmental data generated through FLIM imaging will enable greater coupling of molecular modeling and experimental efforts, enabling the development of more robust simulations that can aide engineers in the design of new systems and materials. Finally, these additions serve as avenues of training for the next generation of great scientists by exposing them to SRM and FLIM. Most importantly, our current cohort of scientists that are utilizing this technology is made of undergraduates, graduate students and postdocs/technicians, and including a number of URMs and women.
